Title: Distributive justice
Content: Distributive justice concerns the socially just allocation of resources in a society. It is concerned with how to allocate resources fairly among members of a society taking into account factors such as wealth income and social status. This subject has been given considerable attention in philosophy and the social sciences. Distributive justice is the arrangement of social political and economic institutions to promote the just distribution of benefits and burdens within a society. Most contemporary theories of distributive justice rest on the precondition of material scarcity. From that preconditions arises the need for principles to resolve competing interest and claims concerning a just or at least morally preferable distribution of scarce resources. Distributive justice is perceived fairness of how rewards and costs are shared by distributed across group members. When some workers work more hours but receive the same pay group members may feel that distributive justice has not occurred. Individuals often turn to the behavioral expectations of their group to determine whether justice has taken place. Five types of distributive norms are defined by Donelson R Forsyth.
